name: Promethazine (Phenergan)
summary: Promethazine is a first-generation antihistamine with strong sedative, antiemetic, and anticholinergic effects, used for allergies, nausea/vomiting, motion sickness, and pre/postoperative sedation.
description: Promethazine, sold under the brand name Phenergan among others, is a phenothiazine derivative with potent H1 receptor antagonism, producing antihistamine and sedative effects. It also has antiemetic, anticholinergic, and moderate dopaminergic antagonist activity. It is indicated for the treatment of allergic conditions, prevention and treatment of nausea and vomiting (including motion sickness), preoperative sedation, and as an adjunct in analgesia. Due to its strong sedative and respiratory depressant effects, it must be used with caution, especially in young children and elderly patients.

contraindications: Children under 2 years (risk of fatal respiratory depression)
monitoring_required: Respiratory status (especially in pediatrics and elderly)

items: Allergic rhinitis and other allergic conditions
Prevention and treatment of nausea and vomiting (including postoperative)

sections.text: Promethazine acts as a competitive H1 receptor antagonist, preventing histamine from binding and exerting its effects. It also has anticholinergic properties that contribute to its antiemetic and sedative effects, and mild dopamine antagonism that enhances anti-nausea benefits.

adult.Allergic conditions: 25 mg at bedtime or 12.5 mg 2–3 times daily
adult.Motion sickness: 25 mg taken 30–60 minutes before travel, then every 12 hours as needed

sections.pediatric: 0.5 mg/kg/dose every 4–6 hours as needed (≥2 years old); maximum single dose 25 mg
sections.geriatric: Start with lowest effective dose; monitor for sedation and orthostatic hypotension

sections.text: Onset: 20 minutes (oral), 5 minutes (IM); Duration: 4–6 hours (up to 12 hours for sedation)

serious: severe tissue injury with IV use

other: Do not use in children under 2 years due to risk of fatal respiratory depression
Caution in elderly due to anticholinergic and sedative effects
IV administration can cause severe tissue damage—prefer oral or IM routes

sections.pregnancy: Category C; use only if potential benefit justifies risk
sections.lactation: Excreted in breast milk—may cause sedation in infant
sections.geriatrics: Greater sensitivity to sedative and anticholinergic effects

sections.text: Not generally required; use as needed for acute symptoms

items: Promethazine is particularly effective for motion sickness prevention when taken before travel
Its sedative properties are sometimes used to enhance analgesic regimens in perioperative care
Avoid parenteral administration unless oral or rectal routes are not feasible
